e4: I recommend changing to the new policy, despite potential short-term benefits, because transparency and accuracy in financial reporting ultimately outweigh potential short-term performance adjustments. Implementing a no-bias policy eliminates concerns of investor manipulation and promotes stability across various investors.
e5: An ethical reporting policy prioritizes transparency, honesty, and accuracy. In this context, an ideal reporting policy allows for timely corrections if initial projections deviate from actual results, yet avoids systematic adjustments or manipulations to better match investor expectations. Considerations may include investors' different levels of financial acumen and how policies might disproportionately impact smaller stakeholders, necessitating caution that any shifts maintain overall fairness and prevent systemic exploitation.
e6: Yes. Some potential follow-up questions might be: What measures would be taken to prevent the negative reaction of smaller investors when changing back from accurate reporting policies? Would the board consider providing supplemental warnings of previous manipulations, in case of a change?
